items.title: Disable test package build
items.body:
### Description of Problem, Request, or Question

I just tried to disable the test packages build in a GitLab-CI pipeline by setting `CPT_TEST_FOLDER` to "False". Unfortunately it is recognized as string instead of boolean, so CPT is searching for the "False" test package directory. 
I also tried by setting the `test_folder` parameter to the actual boolean `False`, but then CPT tries to get the value from `CPT_TEST_FOLDER` (and if not there, sets `test_folder` to `None`).

Is there a valid way to disable the test package build with conan package tools?

### Environment Details
* Conan Package Tools Version: **0.34.0**
* Conan version: **conan 1.27.1**

items.title: [bug] Dependencies are now forced to be built from source
items.body:
Hello,

Thank you for taking the time to read my issue.

### Context

We have been using Conan to build packages for our CPP projects (with GitHub Actions), and since today, we had no problem.

We have implemented a CI with Conan and GitHub Actions, in order to trigger a build every time a commit is pushed on our main branches.

Yesterday, we merged a pull request that triggered a build for one of our project, and the build lasted for around 1 minute. We have added a cache for dependencies, so 1 minute is a normal time for this project.

### Problem

Today, we decided to re-run the build on GitHub Actions manually for the same commit, and this time it took around 4 minutes. By reading the logs, we found out that our dependencies were forced to be built from source.

After running other projects that use the Conan and GitHub Actions integration, all of our builds are taking way too much time, because they are forced to build our dependencies from source (from 3 minutes to 25 minutes).

### Additional test to confirm the problem

We decided to run a new docker container with an Ubuntu 18.04 image, and tried to build one of our projects.

Here is a part of the log we got:

```
protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Forced build from source
srp/0.19@uavia/stable: Forced build from source
boost/1.69.0@conan/stable: Forced build from source
```

Dependencies are also forced to be built from source, even if they are in the `./conan/data`.

### Environment Details
  * Operating System+version: Ubuntu 18.04 (under GitHub Actions)
  * Compiler+version: GCC 7
  * Conan version: 1.26
  * Python version: 3.7.7

### Logs

(1) The build from yesterday on GitHub Actions printed this:

```
srp/0.19@uavia/stable: Forced build from source
Installing package: srp/0.19@uavia/stable
Requirements
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable from 'bincrafters' - Cache
    srp/0.19@uavia/stable from local cache - Cache
Packages
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable:d351525cc53ebe68279edf1978846402420066e7 - Cache
    srp/0.19@uavia/stable:ef98836af63d5f06c8561fdb9e7f89b1f6472869 - Build
Build requirements
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable from 'bincrafters' - Cache
    protoc_installer/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable from 'bincrafters' - Cache
Build requirements packages
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable:d351525cc53ebe68279edf1978846402420066e7 - Skip
    protoc_installer/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable:c0c1ef10e3d0ded44179e28b669d6aed0277ca6a - Cache

Installing (downloading, building) binaries...
protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Already installed!
protoc_installer/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Already installed!
```

(2) And the build today:

```
protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Forced build from source
srp/0.19@uavia/stable: Forced build from source
protoc_installer/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Forced build from source
Installing package: srp/0.19@uavia/stable
Requirements
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable from 'bincrafters' - Cache
    srp/0.19@uavia/stable from local cache - Cache
Packages
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable:d351525cc53ebe68279edf1978846402420066e7 - Build
    srp/0.19@uavia/stable:ef98836af63d5f06c8561fdb9e7f89b1f6472869 - Build
Build requirements
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable from 'bincrafters' - Cache
    protoc_installer/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable from 'bincrafters' - Cache
Build requirements packages
    protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable:d351525cc53ebe68279edf1978846402420066e7 - Build
    protoc_installer/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable:c0c1ef10e3d0ded44179e28b669d6aed0277ca6a - Build

Installing (downloading, building) binaries...
Downloading conan_sources.tgz
protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Configuring sources in /home/runner/.conan/data/protobuf/3.9.1/bincrafters/stable/source

protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Copying sources to build folder
protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Building your package in /home/runner/.conan/data/protobuf/3.9.1/bincrafters/stable/build/d351525cc53ebe68279edf1978846402420066e7
protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Generator cmake created conanbuildinfo.cmake
protobuf/3.9.1@bincrafters/stable: Calling build()
```

### Question

Why our dependencies are now forced to be built from source, instead of using the already installed versions ?

items.title: Update tabulate or relax constraint
items.body:
### Description of Problem, Request, or Question

I am unsure if conan-package-tools needs **exactly** tabulate == 0.8.2, but perhaps trying a `>= 0.8.2` would be nice as I'm getting conflicts with `pandas` in particular.

https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/blob/0d2aab6a9bdfb2c6dca37d58171c9af6ba9e2c6f/cpt/requirements.txt#L3

### Environment Details

* Conan Package Tools Version: **0.31.0**
* Operating System: **Linux**
* Operation System Version: **Ubuntu 18.04**
* Conan version: **conan 1.22.2**
* Python version: **python 3.8.0**

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

I have pandas 1.0.1. If you use the `pd.DataFrame.to_markdown()` you need to use tabulate.
conan-package-tools 0.31.1 forces a strict `tabulate == 0.8.2`, while tabulate is currently at `0.8.6`
As a result, I have incompatible packages and will get an error in pandas if I use 0.8.2

```
ImportError: Pandas requires version '0.8.3' or newer of 'tabulate' (version '0.8.2' currently installed).
```

And vice versa:

```
$ pip install --upgrade tabulate
Processing /home/julien/.cache/pip/wheels/86/8c/d9/3b6c2f55efaefe656c52b725d2fdc5669085c83444979db8b3/tabulate-0.8.6-py3-none-any.whl
ERROR: conan-package-tools 0.31.0 has requirement tabulate==0.8.2, but you'll have tabulate 0.8.6 which is incompatible.
```

I am trying to add an option to my gtest packages only for Debug builds.
However it seems that the option is added to all my builds.

### Environment Details
* Conan Package Tools Version: **0.31.0**
* Conan version: **conan 1.22.2**
* Python version: **python 3.6**

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

```python
builder = ConanMultiPackager(reference="gtest/1.8.1",
            gcc_versions=["7"],
            archs=["x86_64"],
            build_types=["Debug", "Release"],
            options=["gtest:build_gmock=False"])
builder.add_common_builds(pure_c=False)

items.body:
### Feature request
Right now if I `set CONAN_BUILD_TYPES="Debug,Release"` CPT will create two packages for Debug and Release build types.
However CONAN_OPTIONS does not work in the same way. I'm not sure if this is a feature or a bug.

For example, if I `set CONAN_OPTIONS ="foobar:with_bar=True,foobar:with_bar=False"` only one package is created.

items.title: Question: pkg:shared=true for transitive dependencies?
items.body:
Hi I am using conan-package-tools to build multiple packages, depending on each other. I would like to build both static and shared versions.

When building a package with shared option, the package itself is built shared, but it is looking for static dependencies to link with. This might be OK in a special case, but for me when I build a shared library package I would like it to also depend on shared transitive dependencies.

e.g. for building shared openssl depending on shared zlib, I would set zlib:shared=True, openssl:shared=True to make openssl depend on shared zlib.

When I set these options in the environment variable CONAN_OPTIONS while building a package with conan-package-tools these options are also used for building static libs. So I would now get the correct linkage for shared libs, but not for static libs anymore.

I would simply like static libs depend on static libs and shared libs depend on shared libs.

How can I achieve this with package-tools/ConanMultiPackager? This seems to be the common case for me, so there sure is a way for it.

Thanks for any hints

items.title: Question: How to suppress test_package when cross-compiling?
items.body:
There are many test_package conanfiles trying to run produced binaries.

e.g: zlib/1.2.11 on line 23/24:

```python
if "x86" in self.settings.arch:
            self.run(os.path.join("bin", "test"), run_environment=True)
```

Now I am trying to cross-compile this package with mingw from Linux to Windows.

Does this really have to be handled in each package (more or less sophisticated), or should this not be handeld in e.g. self.run(). Or should this already be the case, but I am doing something wrong?

Hope can I suppress running these cross binaries? I am also using conan-package-tools, but this shouldn't be of concern here.

items.title: Add support for the "header_only" option
items.body:
CCI has a special handling for recipes with a `header_only` option and it would be great to have that supported in CPT too

If `header_only` is per default `False`, CPT should add another build where it uses the the other default options but switches `header_only` to `True`

If `header_only` is per default `True`, CPT should add this one header-only default build and then add all the regular combinations with `header_only` set to `False`

items.title: ConanMultiPackager is not compatible with Conanfile's set_name or set_version methods
items.body:
If either of a Conanfile's `name` or `version` fields are replaced with their [corresponding `set_name` or `set_version` methods](https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/reference/conanfile/methods.html?highlight=set_version#set-name-set-version), `ConanMultiPackager` throws an exception. A workaround is to set the environment variable `CONAN_REFERENCE`,  but this is usually not convenient and defeats the purpose of these methods which is to dynamically compute the `name` and `version`.

### Environment Details
* Conan Package Tools Version: **0.30.4**
* Operating System: **Linux**
* Operation System Version: **Fedora 31**
* Conan version: **conan 1.21.1**
* Python version: **python 3.7.6**

### Steps to reproduce

1. Replace the `name` and/or `version` fields of a `Conanfile` with `set_name` and/or `set_version` methods.

```
def set_name(self):
    self.name = "myname"

def set_version(self):
    self.version = "myversion"
```

2. Call `ConanMultiPackager.add_common_builds`.

### Build logs

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "build.py", line 15, in <module>
    builder.add_common_builds(pure_c=False)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cpt/packager.py", line 446, in add_common_builds
    raise Exception("Specify a CONAN_REFERENCE or name and version fields in the recipe")
Exception: Specify a CONAN_REFERENCE or name and version fields in the recipe
```

items.title: [suggestion] Build policy to build all `requirements`
items.body:
Hello!

According to [Conan documentation](https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/reference/commands/creator/create.html) - there is a possibility to build dependencies from sources with avoidance of the binary packages usage.

Currently, the Conan Package Tools propose the three options for the **CONAN_BUILD_POLICY**: **never**, **missing** and **outdated**.

It would be great to have an additional option (e.g: **all**) to build all package dependencies. Such option will add more flexibility during the CI, specially for the cases when the existing binary packages are not suitable for some reason.

items.title: Support partial references

### Description of Problem, Request, or Question

Since Conan 1.19 all packages can be created only using name and version e.g. `zlib/1.2.11`. However, CPT requires an user name and channel so far.

This same feature fixes the case where dependencies are selected to be uploaded, but are partial references:

items.title: Enable not exporting package recipe
items.body:
Currently each build performed by CPT will re-export the package's recipe. It would be beneficial if this behavior could be configured so that builds following the first build do not (re)export the package recipe. The net effect would be the same as specifying the `--not-export` option for the `conan create` command.

Example use case is when choosing to upload a package only after all builds are complete, but where the build dynamically adds content to the package's `export` directory (which is removed each time the package's recipe is exported).

items.title: Question: how to set an env var for just one package
items.body:
Hello,

Conan offer the ability to specify an env variable for just one package.

For example:
```
conan install . -e MyPackage:PATH=/other/path
```

This will set the PATH env var for  MyPackage and **only** MyPackage

Is there a way to achieve the same behaviour with conan-package-tools?

Best,
Walid

items.title: [suggestion] Use numbered jobs
items.body:
For a large build, it's very hard to determine which build is running now because options and configurations could be very similar. Using job numbers simplify log analysis and estimating how much builds has been done currently.

A proposed solution is to use numbered jobs:
- print job numbers at the summary table at CPT start
- print "Build 1/4" before each build

Code for this idea is ready, I can make a PR. Currently it is opt-out via init parameter.

items.title: [bug] package does not get built if already exists in repository
items.body:
Hi there,
I am using the current CPT (0.28.0) and Conan (1.16.0).

My question regards the possibility to force a build even if a package with the same ```packageId``` exists and is ```not outdated```.

The reason behind this is that I have a CI system with build nodes which do not necessarily clear the Conan repository. This means they will always find a "current" recipe and corresponding packages for it.

If I execute the build manually with ```conan create``` or ```conan build``` I can force a build and export of recipe/packages.

Is it possible to force CPT to export and build a recipe regardless if it exists and in what state the existing recipe/packages are (missing/current/outdated)?



EDIT: This relates to another issue I had with CPT and CI build system/nodes: https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/issues/239

items.title: Please add support for cppstd
items.body:
Please add support to `add_common_builds() ` to create builds for various cppstd flags. My recommendation is to provide a build for:
- the default cppstd of a current compiler version (i.e. C++14 for gcc-7 and gcc-8)
- the latest official standard supported by a current compiler version (i.e. C++17 for gcc-7 and gcc-8)
- the pre-release C++ standard if a compiler supports it (i.e. C++2a for gcc-8).

Otherwise, people will be forced to do that by their own in build.py. A short example below assumed the compiler is gcc-7 or gcc-8. It can get much messier when more compilers will be needed (older gcc, clang, VS, etc).

```python
    builder.add_common_builds(pure_c=False)
    new_builds = []
    for settings, options, env_vars, build_requires, reference in builder.items:
        for std in ["17", "20"]:
            if settings["compiler.version"] == "7" and std == "20":
                continue
            new_settings = copy.copy(settings)
            new_settings["cppstd"] = std
            new_builds.append([new_settings, options, env_vars, build_requires])
    builder.builds = new_builds
    builder.run()
```

items.title: add new variable CONAN_CUSTOM_CONANFILE_NAME_OVERRIDE
items.body:
currently, CPT always uses `conanfile.py` as name of conan file containing ConanFile class.
this works flawlessly for the most of use cases, however for the use case installer + library in the same repo (e.g. bison, flex, vulkan, ICU, etc) it's not enough, obviously.
I propose to add new variable named `CONAN_CUSTOM_CONANFILE_NAME_OVERRIDE` to override default.
related code is around here: https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/blob/14c86886eb556d746bef5c167689ee8aedaec810/cpt/runner.py#L89
as you can see, it just always invokes `conan create .` via conan API, and there is no way to use different file name.
in general, I prefer to leave my build scripts untouched (so they match templates), and just specify variable name in travis matrix, like:
```
CONAN_CUSTOM_CONANFILE_NAME_OVERRIDE=bison.py
CONAN_CUSTOM_CONANFILE_NAME_OVERRIDE=bison_installer.py
```
/cc @uilianries

items.title: Docker bind mounts not working on selinux
items.body:
On my local machine with SElinux enabled, building using docker and CPT does not work.
SElinux prevents the docker image to access the contents of the `project` folder.

See https://github.com/conan-io/conan-docker-tools/issues/104#issuecomment-467464786 for an example of this problem.

This can be fixed by adding `:z` or `:Z` to the -v option.
See `man docker run`

from conans import ConanFile

    name = "pkg_base"
    version = "1.2"

from conan.packager import ConanMultiPackager
builder = ConanMultiPackager()
builder.add_common_builds()

items.title: Conan 1.12.0 pip pulling down too new version of pyOpenSSL
items.body:
If host system has a pyOpenSSL outside of spec pip appears to pull down version <19.0.0 (which pulls down 18.0.0), and conan dependency is <18.0.0.

Do not appear to have an issue with 1.11.2, seen on mac osx 10.10 and centos5.

```
$ sudo pip2 install --upgrade pip conan
<snip>
Collecting pyOpenSSL<19.0.0,>=16.0.0 (from conan)
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/96/af/9d29e6bd40823061aea2e0574ccb2fcf72bfd6130ce53d32773ec375458c/pyOpenSSL-18.0.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl (53kB)
<snip>
conan 1.11.2 has requirement pyOpenSSL<18.0.0,>=16.0.0, but you'll have pyopenssl 18.0.0 which is incompatible.
<snip>
[build] $ sh -c 'conan config set log.trace_file=\"/Users/brian/build/conan_home/conan_log.log\" '

    working_set = WorkingSet._build_master()

    return cls._build_from_requirements(__requires__)

Follow on from https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/issues/192

I'm experiencing this error from my Jenkins:

```
----------------------------------------

 Remote date: 1544524100
 Local date: 1539161431
```

Conan version 1.10.1 Windows 

The upload seems to be proceeding, but it causes my Jenkins job to appear to have failed, which is not optimal for our package promotion job.

How would I make use of this ```force=True``` workaround?

items.title: Add UPLOAD_POLICY support
items.body:
Hi!

After Conan 1.9.1 upload command changed and the parameter `force` is gone.

To keep the same behavior we should include upload policy on CPT, otherwise the upload will fail when both recipe dates differ.

items.title: Update README: include remove_if
items.body: Update README file with https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/pull/272

items.title: Don't re-download and re-compress downloaded packages
items.body:
Sometimes there's a situation when part of packages that I wanted to build was build correctly, but something stopped the process (for example, an electricity issue).
Currently I just rerun `python ./build.py` and it downloads built packages and builds packages that are not built. It's much faster than rebuild all packages, but if package is already built, conan-package-tools will:
* download it,
* unpack in,
* compress it.
Looks like conan-package-tools can skip all of these steps because we know that we won't build package from the beginning.
It could save some "network transfers" (as packages won't be downloaded) and CPU time (as packages won't be re-compressed).

items.title: Support custom docker args for docker run command
items.body:
For example: `CONAN_DOCKER_ARGS` and an equivalent constructor argument. 

We've discovered an issue in my company where the default settings for Windows Containers is to allocate 1GB of RAM.  When building particularly large visual studio projects, we get a very random and intermittant compiler error.  This occurs when using multiple versions of Visual Studio Build Tools 15.6.7, 15.7.6, and 15.8.6, and the error references a random C++ template parameter each time, from a variety of different libraries we use. 

```
error C1001: An internal error has occurred in the compiler. 
compiler file 'msc1.cpp', line 1511
```

There are many reports about this error, and Microsoft explains that it's a very generic error that tells them almost nothing.   For us, we've found that it doesn't happen unless we're in Docker, and only on one of our docker hosts, and only on this really big project.  So, we discovered a workaround to be to pass the following additional argument to Docker:   

`-m 2gb`

This doubles the RAM allocated to each container, and the problem seems to have gone away.  However, it's very likely that simply applying this to all builds as part of CPT would have unexpected consequences for other users or even our other projects.  Additionally, there are countless other docker flags which might be necessary to set under certain circumstances. 

As a result, this request is for a primitive catch all string variable that would give users some control over the docker process they are launching, without complicating CPT too much.

items.title: New Environment Variable : PIP_INSTALL=xyz
items.body:
As stated in another ticket, when using CPT to run builds in docker, it will very often be the case that we have additional python packages which contain custom automation code.  Bincrafters has `bincrafters_package_tools`.  My company has our own.  

This seems easy to implement, easy to maintain, etc.  String should even support version pinning if it can handle the = sign.

items.title: Upload package error
items.body:
https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/blob/4b9e3acf9b4a569600aa305a490b2118ab1f311b/cpt/runner.py#L71
test_package dependencies come before created package itself in `r['installed']`
This results in trying to upload non existent package.

items.title: Feature Request: New Environment Variable for "args"
items.body:
I'm not sure if there's a reason this was not created in the first place, but we want to pass Conan args from environment variables for CI. 

`CONAN_ARGS=<project_name>:shared=True, boost:shared=True`

We're implementing this on our own, but would like to see it land in CPT. 

We want this because it's not suitable for us to create conan profiles which go into as much detail as defining the options for projects and their dependencies.  I did try creating project-specific profiles in the project folder, which `include()` global profiles.  It wasn't terrible, but it added to the directory pollution problem, hides information from the person reading the Jenkinsfile, and becomes harder to maintain at scale. There are of course advantages to the project-specific-profiles, and maybe we end up going back to that.  However, it still seems like a reasonable feature to request.

items.title: Feature Request: Add CONAN_CONFIG_URL parameter
items.body:
When added, CPT should run the following prior to the build: 
`conan config install <CONAN_CONFIG_URL>`

items.title: Add quotes to `-v` parameter to support paths with spaces
items.body:
Our local path is..

`c:\jenkins\Some Path With Spaces`

When CPT makes it's `docker run` command, it comes out: 
`docker run c:\jenkins\Some Path With Spaces:whatever`
This causes error:
`docker: invalid reference format: repository name must be lowercase.`

I removed the space in our folder name to workaround the issue.

items.title: Method to disable skip ci check
items.body:
Unrelated commits with `[skip ci]` in the commit message are causing CPT builds to fail with the error
```
Skipped builds due [skip ci] commit message
```
We need a way to disable this check.  for example an `CONAN_DISABLE_SKIP_CI` environment variable.

items.title: Add method remove_if to builder with signature build -> bool
items.body:
The README shows the following example for filtering builds:
```python
    filtered_builds = []
    for settings, options, env_vars, build_requires, reference in builder.items:
        if settings["compiler.version"] != "4.6" and settings["build_type"] != "Debug":
             filtered_builds.append([settings, options, env_vars, build_requires])
    builder.builds = filtered_builds
```

IMO, for short ones, it would be more readable to be able to write something like the following: 

```python
builder.remove_if(lambda build: build.setting["compiler.version"] != "4.6")
```

For slightly longer ones, would like to write something like:
```python
def is_gcc_46_debug(build):
    return build.setting["compiler.version"] != "4.6"` and build.settings["build_type"] != "Debug"

builder.remove_if(lambda build: is_gcc_46_debug(build))
```

I think it's not too hard to implement.  I don't know if we can even do `build.setting` or `build["setting"]`, nor do i know anything about named builds.  I was going to try to implement myself quickly until I saw that, so it will take some extra time to see how that works.  Please just let me know if there are any significant barriers to this one.

items.title: How to use cpt with cmake.install()
items.body:
I developing a conan package for an external project that is built using cmake. It builds & tests just fine locally, but not on gitlab ci. My package is using `cmake.install()` in the `build()` method and just `pass`-ing on the package method as documented [here](https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/howtos/cmake_install.html), and the output looks like it isn't getting anything in the package, with each configuration resulting in output like:
```
CppUTest/master@bryceschober/stable: Generating the package
CppUTest/master@bryceschober/stable: Package folder /home/bschober/.conan/data/CppUTest/master/bryceschober/stable/package/97fa2add7ff02bfbb82a5e5931d282250fb81a2a
CppUTest/master@bryceschober/stable: Calling package()
CppUTest/master@bryceschober/stable: WARN: No files copied from build folder!
CppUTest/master@bryceschober/stable: Package '97fa2add7ff02bfbb82a5e5931d282250fb81a2a' created
```

If I do a local non-cbt build+test along the lines of:
```
conan source .
conan install .
conan build .
conan package .
conan export-pkg -pf package . bryceschober/testing
conan test test_package CppUTest/master@bryceschober/testing
```
Then I get the files that I expect and the test works as expected.

It seems that cbt either doesn't support this "non-standard" but documented / recommended way of reusing the cmake install, or maybe that how do use it with cbt wasn't discoverable by me.

items.title: CONAN_STABLE_BRANCH_PATTERN misinformation
items.body:
`stable_branch_pattern`'s description (both parameter and envvar) states

> if current git branch matches this pattern, the packages will be uploaded to *stable* channel. Default "master"

However in `packager.py _get_channel()` there is such code:

        if self.stable_branch_pattern:
            stable_patterns = [self.stable_branch_pattern]
        else:
            stable_patterns = ["master$", "release*", "stable*"]

meaning that by default the stable channel will be picked not only for `master` branch, but also for branches like `releasetest` or `stable-test`. Do you think it would be worth changing the description or  default patterns to check?

items.title: CONAN_UPLOAD_RETRY doesn't affect anything
items.body:
In `packager.py ConanMultiPackager` there is this line
```self.upload_retry = upload_retry or os.getenv("CONAN_UPLOAD_RETRY", 3)```
but `self.upload_retry` doesn't get passed anywhere later.

items.title: Add support for a post-build step (in-container)
items.body:
The implementation of the `docker_entry_script` was a really good one that has proven useful.  While there is no true `docker_exit_script`, Conan package tools could effectively implement such a thing for users to specify a post-build operation that runs inside the container. 
 
As a prime example, the JFrog CLI enables the uploading of build metadata including the environment variables, git repository and any additional local files desired to Artifactory.  It can also upload other relevant metadata to Bintray.  Downloading and running the JFrog CLI to post this metadata for each CPT build is something we would like to do for our builds.  We also need to conditionally push the binary artifacts to another destination besides Conan, which would be possible if such a feature existed.

items.title: Incorrect warning
items.body:
This warning
```
******* ITERATING THE CONAN_PACKAGE_TOOLS BUILDS WITH .builds is deprecated use .items() instead (unpack 5 elements: settings, options, env_vars, build_requires, reference  *********
```
is misleading: there is no method `.items()` in  `ConanMultiPackager` (`items` as a property), so it should be written as `use .items instead`

items.title: How to upload build dependencies too?
items.body:
I have a package `A` which has other packages (e.g. `B`) as build dependencies. Package `B` is not available as a binary package. When I build `A` with `build_policy` set to `missing` package `B` is build from source as well.

At the end the new package for `A` is uploaded to my repo. Is it possible to automatically upload the new package for `B` as well?

items.title: Trigger new test by Conan release
items.body:
Hi!

I have used Gitlab triggers to start a new build for project B, when the project A have a new releases.

WDYT about start a new CI job for CPT when a Conan release is created?

My intention is to make sure that any new release will not break CPT (in the future). I saw this problem few times, but was for Conan 0.x.x.

items.title: Bomboo env vars error
items.body:
I'm the original proposer for de-bambooizing conan env vars but was mistaken by bamboo declaration of global vars and effective env var creation.

Setting `CONAN_USERNAME` as a global variable makes `${bamboo.CONAN_USERNAME}` available throughout bamboo scripts/commands and creates a `bamboo_CONAN_USERNAME` env var for the CI process.

items.title: Add custom test folder support
items.body:
Hi!

I would like to be able to pass `--test-folder` option to Conan create command.

As you can see [here](https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/blob/develop/cpt/runner.py#L69), the command only uses the reference, profile and policy.

I need to change the test_package path in a project, Conan won't be able to execute the tests by CPT.

Before to check the code, I tried to use CPT args to set the option, I thought that in the past this would work.

    builder = ConanMultiPackager(args=['--test-folder', 'conan/test_package'])

I could help to implement this feature, but I would like to discuss before to start. Conan client doesn't support customization by env vars in this case, so we could add new argument or re-use something.

items.title: Pass args=["--build", "missing"] to "conan create"?
items.body:
I must be missing something but
```python
    builder = ConanMultiPackager(args=["--build", "missing"])
    # ...
```
does not affect `conan create`, internally invoked by `builder.run()`. Docs says that's OK:
- **args**: List with the parameters that will be passed to "conan test" command. e.j: args=['--build', 'all']. Default sys.argv[1:]

But I'm under impression it worked before....

I also thought that `build_policy = "missing"` should affect dependent recipes, but no, only `conan create ... --build missing` would help. Is it expected behavior?

https://github.com/conan-io/conan-package-tools/pull/205/files

It's a trivial change.  Will try to do ASAP.

items.title: cleanup conan_runner container on various failures
items.body:
CPT current exits after various failures surrounding the `conan_runner` docker container, leaving it dangling.  Then, subsequent runs of CPT will fail with the error:

`docker: Error response from daemon: Conflict. The container name "/conan_runner" is already in use by container`

We need to cleanup `conan_runner` reliably after every run.

items.title: Add workaround for LCOW USER bug
items.body:
Currently the use of LCOW is blocked by a bug with docker-for-windows.  LCOW start with the user set to `root` regardless of what is set in `Dockerfile`, while CPT assumes the user is `conan` (more importantly, that `pwd` is `/home/conan`.  The suggestion here is to add `sudo su conan && ` when LCOW is detected. Currently, CPT has no concept of LCOW, so that would need to be added also.  

The issue for the user problem on LCOW is documented here:
https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/36469

There are other ways to workaround the issue, this one just seemed fine.

items.title: suggest move split_colon_env function to tools
items.body:
This function seems a better fit for tools.py than builds_generator.py:
```
def split_colon_env(varname):
    return [a.strip() for a in list(filter(None, os.getenv(varname, "").split(",")))]
```
We use it in `bincrafters_package_tools`

items.title: Need two CONAN_DOCKER_SUDO variables
items.body:
There are two places where `sudo` might be used in Conan Package Tools:
1. When invoking docker commands:  `sudo docker run ...`
2. When invoking pip commands inside the container:  `sudo pip install conan_package_tools...`

These are fundamentally different and we need separate handling, so please start by defining a separate variable for inside the container.  In particular, Linux containers on Windows will need `sudo` inside the container, but not outside.

items.title: Jenkins Plugin Does Not Upload From Remote Build Slave
items.body:
I am using the artifactory jenkins plugin - all items are the latest and greatest as of 4/14/2018
Declarative pipeline; building on a remote node
Everything works great and packages are created/exported
When it comes time to upload however, using the examples for how to do the upload fail.
No packages found. Is the error emitted.

Here is the basic pattern suggested from the docs. Note: I have tried NUMEROUS changes and combinations of this example (and I have it in declarative syntax). So lets not focus on that stuff - if possible.

The pattern suggested is something like (I have tried dozens of combinations etc) :

def artifactory_name = ...
def artifactory_repo = ...

node {
    def server = Artifactory.server artifactory_name
    def client = Artifactory.newConanClient()
    def serverName = client.remote.add server: server, repo: artifactory_repo

    stage("Get recipe"){
        git branch: repo_branch, url: repo_url
    }

...

    stage("Upload packages"){
        String command = "upload * --all -r ${serverName} --confirm"
        def b = client.run(command: command)
        server.publishBuildInfo b
    }
}

I think the problem is that, the client.run (command: ...  Does NOT run on the build slave.

Rather it runs on my jenkins/artifactory server. 
And so there are in fact no packages - and there shouldn't be.


The question:
How would I get the run command (upload) to execute on the build slave ?
(I actually did a good bit of searching/looking; so this could easily be my error, but it is not knee jerk)

Ubuntu 17.10 
Jenkins 2.107.1
Plugin 2.15.1
Artifactory 5.10.1  (the community c++ distribution if that matters)

items.title: CONAN_DOCKER_IMAGE_SKIP_UPDATE doesn't work with conan docker tools
items.body:
None of the images in conan_docker_tools install `conan_package_tools` by default.  So, if one uses `CONAN_DOCKER_IMAGE_SKIP_UPDATE` or the constructor parameter of the same name, builds will fail because there will be no script named `run_create_in_docker` in the container.  

Let me know if i've missed something.  If not, I can understand why one would skip installing `conan_package_tools` in the container, but since you do install `conan` in the container... it makes less sense.
